direct_answer.text: To solve the equation $(\sqrt{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})+(\sqrt{3}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}})$, first combine each pair separately since addition allows combining unlike terms freely. For the pair \(\sqrt{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\), notice that multiplying top and bottom of \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) by \(\sqrt{2}\) transforms it into \(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\). Now add it to \(\sqrt{2}\), getting \(\sqrt{2}+\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\). Combining similar terms results in \(\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2}\). Repeat a similar procedure for the second part: convert \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\) to \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}\) via multiplication of numerator and denominator by \(\sqrt{3}\). Adding this to \(\sqrt{3}\) leads to \(\sqrt{3}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}\), simplified to \(\frac{4\sqrt{3}}{3}\). Summing these converted forms gets \(\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2}+\frac{4\sqrt{3}}{3}\).
